Award.AwardTitle: Undergraduate Research in Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: The Ohio State University's Departments of Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry will host an REU program for 12 students during the summers of 2011-2015. The objective of the 9-week internship is to provide an intense research experience in molecular life sciences that allows students to discover first-hand the excitement of being an independent scientist. As a complement to the research component, students will gain experience in scientific communication, attend an undergraduate research conference, visit core facilities, explore the responsibilities that come with being a scientist, and equip themselves with information vital for entering graduate programs and careers in the life sciences. Faculty from the Departments of Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics, with proven track records in supporting undergraduate research, will serve as mentors. The program offers a rich array of different research opportunities with a common thematic basis that promotes interaction at all levels. After an initial short laboratory workshop, which will provide students with a set of basic technical skills, the students will spend their remaining time working in a laboratory chosen based on their own research interest. During this period, they will receive training and be encouraged to develop independence in formulating hypotheses, designing experiments, analyzing data and troubleshooting. At the end of the summer, students will present a poster to summarize their results at an undergraduate conference and at a poster session for scientists in both departments. The impact of the program will be assessed by using a common survey adopted by all REU sites. The program is primarily designed for students currently at undergraduate institutions where there are limited chances to do research. A strong academic background is desired but signs of promise, other than GPA, will also be taken into serious consideration. These will be primarily personal recommendations by faculty members. Students from groups underrepresented in science are strongly encouraged to apply. All applications will be processed through the program website (http://www.biosci.ohio-state.edu/%7Emgmajors/REU/). Additional information can be found at the website as well us by contacting the program administrator Debbie Dotter (dotter.4@osu.edu) or the PI, Dr Amanda Simcox (simcox.1@osu.edu).

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goals of the REU program are to increase the diversity, number, and quality of future scientists. The future of scientific research hinges on the strength of graduate education, and given the changing demographics of the US population, it become more critical to foster the development of a pool of excellent young scientists who represent the current US population. The REU Site In Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry seeks to:

  • provide opportunities for students from historically under-represented groups in science
  • provide experiences for students from institutions with limited research opportunities
  • strengthen the credentials of students with average academic records to enhance their potential
  • increase opportunities for students with already strong academic records 

We provided summer research experiences for 60 students between 2011 and 2016. These students spent 9 weeks on the Ohio State University campus, conducting independent research in a mentor laboratory. They also took part in research training, ethics training, networking opportunities and professional development activities designed to promote and nurture their commitment to scientific research, and build connections with the scientific community. To date, of the 43 participants who have graduated from college, over 50% have entered graduate programs in the sciences, with an additional 19% in a professional school (predominantly medical school) and 17% pursuing careers in research or teaching.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

Students taking part in the program contribute to ongoing research in host labs. The research programs use model organisms to address fundamental questions in biology, ranging from tRNA metabolism to vertebrate development to plant cellular biology among others. In addition, through their engagement in writing programs and presentation of a final poster, students will become stronger communicators with a deeper understanding of science. Although it is difficult for a student to complete a body of work in a 9-week summer internship that is sufficient for publication, we have requested that mentors make every effort to design self-contained projects that provide outstanding training while allowing the participant the possibility to generate data for a figure that will appear in a publication. This strategy has led to inclusion of an REU participant as a co-author on 12 papers published by OSU mentors to date, as well as many papers in preparation from more recent years. As students enter graduate school and continue their education, we anticipate that they will contribute to diverse research programs outside of Ohio State, and indeed former participants have contributed to at least 15 additional manuscripts reporting research unconnected with the program.

BROADER IMPACTS

This program had wide broader impacts, mostly related to "advancing discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning" and "broadening participation of under-represented groups". The program provided undergraduate research training for groups under-represented in science, and for students with limited research opportunities. 65% of our participants came from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. 57% attended undergraduate institutions that do not offer a PhD in the sciences, and 27% were the first in their family to attend college. Our data from program assessments demonstrate that the REU experience positively influenced students to pursue graduate education and research careers, with 36% of students indicating a higher likelihood of continuing to graduate school due to this program and an additional 18% indicating that the they feel more confident in their ability to succeed in graduate school. To date, >50% of previous participants have entered a graduate program after graduation from college, and thus we expect that the majority of these students will continue into graduate education, and many will make important contributions to scientific knowledge.
